texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: AMD's new  Zen 4 processors  started rolling out in 2022 and I've been watching for the mobile CPUs to reach laptops. I like where AMD is going with these chips and how they provide lots of CPU power without eating up the battery.
texts.text: AMD's new  Zen 4 processors  started rolling out in 2022 and I've been watching for the mobile CPUs to reach laptops. I like where AMD is going with these chips and how they provide lots of CPU power without eating up the battery.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I recently ordered a  ThinkPad Z13 Gen 2  with an AMD Ryzen 7. As you might expect, I loaded it up with Fedora Linux and set out to ensure that everything works.
texts.text: I recently ordered a  ThinkPad Z13 Gen 2  with an AMD Ryzen 7. As you might expect, I loaded it up with Fedora Linux and set out to ensure that everything works.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This post includes all of the configurations and changes I added along the way.
texts.text: This post includes all of the configurations and changes I added along the way.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Power management
texts.text: Power management

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I removed the power profiles daemon that comes with Fedora by default. and replaced it with  tlp . This is a great package for ThinkPad laptops as it takes care of most of the power management configuration for you with sane defaults. It also offers an easy to read configuration file where you can make adjustments.
texts.text: I removed the power profiles daemon that comes with Fedora by default. and replaced it with  tlp . This is a great package for ThinkPad laptops as it takes care of most of the power management configuration for you with sane defaults. It also offers an easy to read configuration file where you can make adjustments.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The defaults seem to be working well so far, but my only complaint is that the power management for
texts.text: The defaults seem to be working well so far, but my only complaint is that the power management for

texts.label: code
texts.orig: amdgpu
texts.text: amdgpu

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: seems to be  really aggressive . Graphics performance on battery power is  okay , but I'm told this improves in kernel 6.7. I'm on 6.6.11 in Fedora 39 right now.
texts.text: seems to be  really aggressive . Graphics performance on battery power is  okay , but I'm told this improves in kernel 6.7. I'm on 6.6.11 in Fedora 39 right now.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'll wait to see if this new kernel makes any improvements.
texts.text: I'll wait to see if this new kernel makes any improvements.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Touchpad
texts.text: Touchpad

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The ELAN touchpad in the Z13 is a bit different. It's a  haptic  touchpad. It doesn't push down with a click like the other thinkpads. It provides haptic feedback, much like a mobile phone does when you tap on the screen. (I usually turn this off on my phone, but it feels good on the laptop.)
texts.text: The ELAN touchpad in the Z13 is a bit different. It's a  haptic  touchpad. It doesn't push down with a click like the other thinkpads. It provides haptic feedback, much like a mobile phone does when you tap on the screen. (I usually turn this off on my phone, but it feels good on the laptop.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The touchpad works right out of the box without any additional configuration. I made a basic Sway configuration stanza to get it configured with my preferences:
texts.text: The touchpad works right out of the box without any additional configuration. I made a basic Sway configuration stanza to get it configured with my preferences:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# ThinkPad Z13 Gen 2 AMD Touchpad
input "11311:40:SNSL0028:00_2C2F:0028_Touchpad" {
  drag disabled
  tap enabled
  dwt enabled
  natural_scroll disabled
}
texts.text:
# ThinkPad Z13 Gen 2 AMD Touchpad
input "11311:40:SNSL0028:00_2C2F:0028_Touchpad" {
  drag disabled
  tap enabled
  dwt enabled
  natural_scroll disabled
}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The configuration above enables tap to click and dragging with taps. I like the old school scrolling style and I've disabled the natural scroll.
texts.text: The configuration above enables tap to click and dragging with taps. I like the old school scrolling style and I've disabled the natural scroll.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can always get a list of your input devices in Sway with
texts.text: You can always get a list of your input devices in Sway with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: swaymsg
texts.text: swaymsg

texts.label: code
texts.orig: swaymsg -t get_inputs
texts.text: swaymsg -t get_inputs

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Display
texts.text: Display

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The display worked right out of the box but the UI elements were scaled up far too large for me. I typically value screen real estate over all other aspects, but my usual default of scaling to 1.0 made the UI far too small.
texts.text: The display worked right out of the box but the UI elements were scaled up far too large for me. I typically value screen real estate over all other aspects, but my usual default of scaling to 1.0 made the UI far too small.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I set my output scaling to 1.2:
texts.text: I set my output scaling to 1.2:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Disable HiDPI
output * scale 1.2
texts.text:
# Disable HiDPI
output * scale 1.2

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I also enabled the  RPM Fusion repos  to get the freeworld AMD Mesa drivers:
texts.text: I also enabled the  RPM Fusion repos  to get the freeworld AMD Mesa drivers:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
sudo dnf install \
    https://mirrors.rpmfusion.org/free/fedora/rpmfusion-free-release-$(rpm -E %fedora).noarch.rpm \
    https://mirrors.rpmfusion.org/nonfree/fedora/rpmfusion-nonfree-release-$(rpm -E %fedora).noarch.rpm
sudo dnf swap mesa-va-drivers mesa-va-drivers-freeworld
sudo dnf swap mesa-vdpau-drivers mesa-vdpau-drivers-freeworld
texts.text:
sudo dnf install \
    https://mirrors.rpmfusion.org/free/fedora/rpmfusion-free-release-$(rpm -E %fedora).noarch.rpm \
    https://mirrors.rpmfusion.org/nonfree/fedora/rpmfusion-nonfree-release-$(rpm -E %fedora).noarch.rpm
sudo dnf swap mesa-va-drivers mesa-va-drivers-freeworld
sudo dnf swap mesa-vdpau-drivers mesa-vdpau-drivers-freeworld

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Audio
texts.text: Audio

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sound worked right out of the box, but I found that the loudness preset from  easyeffects  made the speakers sound a little bit better:
texts.text: Sound worked right out of the box, but I found that the loudness preset from  easyeffects  made the speakers sound a little bit better:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: sudo dnf install easyeffects
texts.text: sudo dnf install easyeffects

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Everything else
texts.text: Everything else

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Everything else just worked!
texts.text: Everything else just worked!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm really pleased with the performance and the battery life so far. My only complaint is that the OLED screen can be a battery hog at times.
texts.text: I'm really pleased with the performance and the battery life so far. My only complaint is that the OLED screen can be a battery hog at times.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For more details, check out the  Arch Linux wiki page for the Z13 . They documented lots of the function keys if you want to create keyboard shortcuts and they link to some downloadable monitor profiles.
texts.text: For more details, check out the  Arch Linux wiki page for the Z13 . They documented lots of the function keys if you want to create keyboard shortcuts and they link to some downloadable monitor profiles.
